botanical_details.genus: Clematis can be deciduous or evergreen shrubs or herbaceous perennials, mostly climbing by twining leaf-stalks, and often with showy flowers. Some have attractive fluffy seedheads in autumn
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Late Large-flowered clematis are deciduous climbers with large, star-shaped flowers to 15cm wide, opening on the current year's growth in summer and autumn

how_to_grow.cultivation: Plant in moisture-retentive, well-drained soil, with the roots and base of the plant kept cool and shaded by other plants or a layer of pebbles at the base. Plant with the crown 5-8cm deep to encourage new shoots to grow from below ground level. Ideal for containers, including hanging baskets. See clematis cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate from cuttings (climbers) or by layering, for home use
how_to_grow.pruning: Pruning (clematis) group 2, light prune for early flowers. Remove dead and damaged stems before growth begins in early spring. Trim all remaining stems to strong buds. Hard prune for easy-care option using Pruning (clematis) group 3
how_to_grow.pests: Young shoots may be troubled by aphids and caterpillars; petals can be eaten by earwigs
how_to_grow.diseases: May suffer from clematis wilt, clematis green petal and clematis slime flux
